heading: 3.1 Residual Plots in ggplot2
code:
# residual size plot
library(ggplot2)
bac <- read.csv("https://raw.githubusercontent.com/deepbas/statdatasets/main/BAC.csv")

fit <- lm(BAC ~ Beers, data = bac) # fit the model
bac$predicted <- predict(fit)   # Save the predicted values
bac$residuals <- residuals(fit) # Save the residual values

ggplot(bac, aes(x = Beers, y = BAC)) +
  geom_smooth(method = "lm", se = FALSE, color = "lightgrey") +     # regression line  
  geom_segment(aes(xend = Beers, yend = predicted), alpha = .2) +      # draw line from point to line
  geom_point(aes(color = abs(residuals), size = abs(residuals))) +  # size of the points
  scale_color_continuous(low = "green", high = "red") +   
  labs(title = "BAC Vs. Beers") +# color of the points mapped to residual size - green smaller, red larger
  guides(color = FALSE, size = FALSE) +                             # Size legend removed
  geom_point(aes(y = predicted), shape = 1, size = 2) +
  scale_x_continuous(breaks=1:9)+
  theme(axis.text=element_text(size=10),
        axis.title=element_text(size=10,face="bold"),
        plot.title = element_text(size = 10, face = "bold"))
ggplot(bac, aes(x = Beers, y = residuals)) +
  geom_point() +
  theme(legend.position = "none") +
  geom_segment(aes(xend = Beers, yend = 0), alpha = .2) +
  scale_color_continuous(low = "green", high = "red") +   
  geom_point(aes(color = abs(residuals), size = abs(residuals))) +  # size of the points
  geom_hline(yintercept = 0, col = "blue", size = 0.5, linetype = "dashed") + 
  labs(title = "BAC Vs. Beers",
       x = "Beers",
       y = "Residuals") +
  theme(plot.title = element_text(hjust=0.5, size=7, face='bold'))

heading: 3.2 Plotly codes
code:
library(plotly)

cell_phone_data <- data.frame(
  Type = c("Android", "iPhone", "Blackberry", "Non Smartphone", "No Cell Phone"),
  Frequency = c(458, 437, 141, 924, 293)
)

data <- data.frame(
  Gender = c("Female", "Male"),
  In_a_relationship = c(32, 10),
  Its_complicated = c(12, 7),
  Single = c(63, 45)
)
plot_ly(cell_phone_data, labels = ~Type, values = ~Frequency, type = 'pie',
        textposition = 'inside', hoverinfo = 'label+value+percent',
        textinfo = 'label', insidetextfont = list(color = '#FFFFFF')) %>%
  layout(title = 'Cell Phone Usage',
         xaxis = list(showgrid = FALSE, zeroline = FALSE, showticklabels = FALSE),
         yaxis = list(showgrid = FALSE, zeroline = FALSE, showticklabels = FALSE))
plot_ly(data, x = ~Gender, y = ~In_a_relationship, type = 'bar', name = 'In a relationship') %>%
  add_trace(y = ~Its_complicated, name = 'It\'s complicated') %>%
  add_trace(y = ~Single, name = 'Single') %>%
  layout(yaxis = list(title = 'Number of People'), barmode = 'group')

heading: 5 Graph Formatting
text: worksheet provides comprehensive guide graph formatting R using ggplot2 package. explore various aspects formatting, adding figure numbers, captions, titles, axes labels, customizing themes, using different color scales.

heading: 5.1 Load the required packages and datasets
code: Cereals <- read.csv("http://people.carleton.edu/~kstclair/data/Cereals.csv")

heading: 5.2.1 Adding figure numbers and captions
text:
automatically add figure numbers captions, include option fig_caption: true output options top markdown file. add captions figures, use fig.cap argument R code chunk creates figure.
Figure 5.1: nice figure
code:
ggplot(Cereals, aes(x = calgram)) +
  geom_histogram(binwidth = 0.3, fill = "skyblue", color = "black") +
  labs(title = "Histogram of Calorie Content in Cereals",
       x = "Calorie Content (g)",
       y = "Count") +
  theme_minimal()

heading: 5.2.2 Customizing titles, axis labels, and legends
text: can customize titles, axis labels, legends using labs() function.
code:
ggplot(data = diamonds, aes(x = carat, y = price, color = cut)) +
  geom_point(alpha = 0.5) +
  labs(title = "Price vs. Carat of Diamonds",
       subtitle = "Color represents the cut of the diamond",
       x = "Carat",
       y = "Price (USD)",
       color = "Diamond Cut") +
  theme_minimal()

heading: 5.2.3 Customizing themes
text: can customize themes using theme() function various element_*() functions.
code:
ggplot(mtcars, aes(x = hp, y = mpg)) +
  geom_point() +
  labs(title = "Miles per Gallon vs. Horsepower",
       x = "Horsepower",
       y = "Miles per Gallon") +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(plot.title = element_text(size = 16, face = "bold", color = "darkblue"),
        axis.title = element_text(size = 12, face = "bold", color = "darkblue"),
        axis.text = element_text(size = 10, color = "black"),
        panel.grid.major = element_line(color = "gray", size = 0.5),
        panel.grid.minor = element_line(color = "gray", size = 0.25))

heading: 5.2.4 Using different color scales
text:
can use different color scales continuous discrete variables using scale_color_*() scale_fill_*() functions.
Figure 5.2: Figure 4: Scatterplot price vs. carat diamonds color representing cut custom color scale.
code:
ggplot(data = diamonds, aes(x = carat, y = price, color = cut)) +
  geom_point(alpha = 0.5) +
  labs(title = "Price vs. Carat of Diamonds",
       subtitle = "Color represents the cut of the diamond",
       x = "Carat",
       y = "Price (USD)",
       color = "Diamond Cut") +
  scale_color_brewer(palette = "Set1") +
  theme_minimal()

heading: 5.2.5 Customizing plot elements
text: can customize plot elements points, lines, bars using corresponding geom_*() functions arguments.
code:
ggplot(mtcars, aes(x = hp, y = mpg, shape = factor(gear), size = gear)) +
  geom_point(aes(color = factor(gear))) +
  labs(title = "Miles per Gallon vs. Horsepower",
       x = "Horsepower",
       y = "Miles per Gallon",
       color = "Number of Gears",
       shape = "Number of Gears",
       size = "Number of Gears") +
  theme_minimal() +
  scale_shape_manual(values = c(16, 17, 18)) +
  scale_color_brewer(palette = "Set2")

heading: 5.2.6 Faceting
text: can create multiple plots based categorical variable using facet_wrap() facet_grid() functions.
code:
ggplot(data = diamonds %>% filter(carat < 3), aes(x = carat, y = price)) +
  geom_point(aes(color = clarity), alpha = 0.5) +
  labs(title = "Price vs. Carat of Diamonds",
       x = "Carat",
       y = "Price (USD)",
       color = "Clarity") +
  facet_wrap(~ cut, ncol = 2) +
  theme_minimal()

# Load the built-in datasets

heading: 5.3.6 Adjusting the size of facet labels

geom_point(alpha = 0.5) +

heading: 5.3.7 Adjusting the size of axis ticks
text:
can modify size axis ticks using theme() function along element_line().
Figure 5.3: Figure 6: Scatterplot mpg vs. hp customized axis tick size.
code:

heading: 5.3.8 Adding text labels to points
text: Use geom_text() geom_label() functions add text labels points.
code:
mtcars$car_name <- rownames(mtcars)

scatter_plot_labels <- ggplot(mtcars, aes(x = wt, y = mpg)) +
  geom_point(aes(color = gear)) +
  geom_text(aes(label = car_name), check_overlap = TRUE, vjust = 1.5) +
  labs(title = "Scatter plot of MPG vs Weight with Car Labels",
       x = "Weight",
       y = "Miles Per Gallon",
       color = "Gears")

scatter_plot_labels

heading: 5.3.9 Modifying axis limits and scales
text: Use scale_x_continuous() scale_y_continuous() modify axis limits scales.
code:
data("gapminder", package = "gapminder")

ggplot(gapminder, aes(x = gdpPercap, y = lifeExp, color = continent)) +
  geom_point() +
  scale_x_log10() +
  scale_x_continuous(limits = c(500, 50000), breaks = c(1000, 10000, 30000), labels = scales::dollar_format()) +
  scale_y_continuous(limits = c(20, 90), breaks = seq(20, 90, 10)) +
  labs(title = "Life Expectancy vs. GDP per Capita",
       x = "GDP per Capita (log scale)",
       y = "Life Expectancy")

heading: 6.0.7 Summary statistics with pander
text: can use pander package create summary tables.Summary statistics miles per gallon

#install.packages("pander")
library(pander)
pander(summary(mtcars$mpg), caption = "Summary statistics for miles per gallon")

heading: 6.0.8 t-test results with pander
text: Let’s perform t-test comparing miles per gallon (mpg) cars 4 6 cylinders.Comparing MPG 4 6 cylinder cars (continued )
code:
t_test_result <- t.test(mpg ~ as.factor(cyl), data = mtcars, subset = cyl %in% c(4, 6))
pander(t_test_result, caption = "Comparing MPG for 4 and 6 cylinder cars")

heading: 6.0.9 Chi-square test results with pander
text: Now let’s perform chi-square test check association number cylinders type transmission (automatic manual).Chi-square test cylinders transmission type
code:
my_table <- table(mtcars$cyl, mtcars$am)
chisq_test_result <- chisq.test(my_table)
pander(chisq_test_result, caption = "Chi-square test for cylinders and transmission type")

heading: 6.0.10 Linear regression results with pander
text: Finally, let’s fit linear regression model miles per gallon (mpg) function weight (wt) display results.Linear regression MPG weight
code:
lm_result <- lm(mpg ~ wt, data = mtcars)
pander(lm_result, caption = "Linear regression of MPG on weight")

heading: 12.2 Example 2: Z-scores for Test Scores
text: ACT test population mean 21 standard deviation 5. SAT population mean 1500 standard deviation 325. earned 28 ACT 2100 SAT.

heading: 12.2.1 (a) Which test did you do better on?
text:
Answer:ACT: z-score score 28 z = (28 - 21)/5 = 1.4.SAT: z-score score 2100 z = (2100 - 1500)/325 = 1.85.SAT score 1.85 standard deviations average ACT score 1.4 standard
deviations . better SAT.

heading: 12.2.2 (b) For each test, find the interval that is likely to contain about 95% of all test scores.
text:
Answer:ACT: Two standard deviations 2(5) = 10. 95% ACT scores 21 - 10 = 11
21 + 10 = 31. claim assumes ACT scores follow bell-shaped distribution.SAT: Two standard deviations 2(325) = 650. 95% SAT scores 1500 - 650 =
850 1500 + 650 = 2150. claim assumes SAT scores follow bell-shaped distribution.
code:
ACT_lower <- 21 - 2 * 5
ACT_upper <- 21 + 2 * 5
SAT_lower <- 1500 - 2 * 325
SAT_upper <- 1500 + 2 * 325
c(ACT_lower, ACT_upper)[1] 11 31
c(SAT_lower, SAT_upper)[1]  850 2150

hotdog_q1 <- quantile(hotdogs$HotDogs, 0.25)
hotdog_q3 <- quantile(hotdogs$HotDogs, 0.75)
hotdog_iqr <- IQR(hotdogs$HotDogs)
lower_fence <- hotdog_q1 - 1.5 * hotdog_iqr
upper_fence <- hotdog_q3 + 1.5 * hotdog_iqr

library(dplyr)
outliers <- filter(hotdogs, HotDogs < lower_fence | HotDogs > upper_fence)

text: Use boxplot outlier rule find “fence” (cutoff) outlier non-outlier WorldGross. determine value (WorldGross) upper “whisker” (non-outlier) extends .Answer:Create new dataset called movies_no_outliers contains rows movies_no_na WorldGross values within range defined lower upper fences.Answer:
code:
library(tidyr)
movies_no_na <- drop_na(movies) 
q1_world_gross <- quantile(movies_no_na$WorldGross, 0.25)
q3_world_gross <- quantile(movies_no_na$WorldGross, 0.75)
iqr_world_gross <- IQR(movies_no_na$WorldGross)
lower_fence_world_gross <- q1_world_gross - 1.5 * iqr_world_gross
upper_fence_world_gross <- q3_world_gross + 1.5 * iqr_world_gross

outliers <- filter(movies_no_na, WorldGross < lower_fence_world_gross | WorldGross > upper_fence_world_gross)

heading: 14.4 Example 3: Simulation of a Sample Proportion
text: According PEW survey, \(66\%\) U.S. adult citizens casted ballot 2020 election. Suppose take random sample \(n=100\) eligible U.S. voters computed sample proportion voted.
code:
# Call the library
library(ggplot2)
# Define parameters
pop.prop <- .66 # Population proportion
n.size <- 100  # sample size

heading: 14.4.1 (a) Generate a random sample of size \(n= 100\) and plot its sample proportion.
code:
# Generate 1 sample
sample1 <- rbinom(n = 1, size = n.size, p = pop.prop) # R simulates the samples
sample.prop1 <- sample1/n.size #  Proportion = No. of Success / Sample Size
# define a data frame
mydata <- data.frame(x = sample.prop1)

# Plot a dot plot of the sample proportion
ggplot(mydata, aes(x = x)) +
   geom_dotplot(dotsize = 0.25,
               stackratio = 0.75,
               binwidth = .025,
               color = "gold",
               fill = "blue") +
  ggtitle("A single sample proportion") +  xlab("Proportion") + ylab("Count")+
  scale_x_continuous(limits = c(0, 1))+ 
  theme(plot.title = element_text(hjust = 0.5))

heading: 14.4.2 (b) Generate 5 random samples of size \(n= 100\) and plot the sample proportions.
code:
# generate 5 random samples of size 100
sample5 <- rbinom(n = 5, size = n.size, p = pop.prop)  
sample.prop5 <- sample5/n.size 

data <- data.frame(x = sample.prop5)

ggplot(data, aes(x = x)) +
   geom_dotplot(dotsize = 0.25,
               stackratio = 0.75,
               binwidth = .025,
               color = "gold",
               fill = "blue") +
  ggtitle("") +  xlab("Proportion") + ylab("Count")+
  scale_x_continuous(limits = c(0, 1))+ 
  theme(plot.title = element_text(hjust = 0.5))

heading: 14.4.3 (c) Generate 500 random samples of size \(n= 100\) and plot the sample proportions.

heading: 20.4.3 (c) Adjusting the Significance Level

Explain reasoning.Answer: decrease chance making Type error, school administration choose smaller significance level, 0.01 instead typical 0.05. using smaller significance level, require stronger evidence (smaller p-value) reject null hypothesis, thus reducing probability making Type error.

heading: 20.4.4 (d) Factors Influencing Type II Error Rate
text: List factors influence probability making Type II error briefly describe affect error rate context.Answer: Factors influence probability making Type II error include:Effect size: true difference new teaching method traditional method. larger effect size makes easier detect difference, reducing Type II error rate.Sample size: number students involved study. larger sample size increases power test, making likely detect true difference reducing Type II error rate.Variability: amount variation students’ learning outcomes. Higher variability makes difficult detect true difference, increasing Type II error rate.Significance level: chosen significance level (alpha) also affects Type II error rate. larger significance level (e.g., 0.10) decreases Type II error rate increases Type error rate.

Ultimately, administration choose significance level sample size balance risks associated Type Type II errors taking account practical constraints priorities.

heading: 22.1 Example 1: SAT Verbal scores
text: Suppose verbal SAT scores population normally distributed mean \(\mu=580\) standard deviation \(\sigma = 70\). \(X\) shorthand verbal SAT score, can write \(X \sim N(580,70)\).

heading: 22.1.0.1 (a) What proportion of scores are above 650?
text: Answer: 15.9% scores 650.
code:
pnorm(650,mean=580,sd=70) # proportion below[1] 0.8413447
1-pnorm(650,mean=580,sd=70) # proportion above[1] 0.1586553

heading: 22.1.0.2 (b) What is the 25th percentile (Q1)?
text: Answer: score 533 25th percentile, meaning 25% scores value.

heading: 22.1.0.3 (c) What is the IQR for verbal SAT scores in this population? (Hint: find Q1 and Q3)
text: Answer: 25th percentile (Q1) 533 75th percentile (Q3) 627. IQR normally distributed variable 94 points.

heading: 22.1.0.4 (d) What score, high or low, will be deemed an outlier according the boxplot rules for outliers?
text: Answer: Using 1.5IQR’s boxplot rule gives lower fence 392 upper fence 768. score 392 768 called outlier according rule.

heading: 22.1.0.5 (e) What percent of the population will be deemed an outlier?
text: Answer: need find proportion scores 392 768. symmetric distribution, find 0.004 tails. 0.8% population deemed outliers according boxplot rule.

heading: 22.2 Example 2: Standard Normal
text: standard normal distribution mean 0 standard deviation 1.

heading: 22.2.0.1 (a) What percent of SAT scores are at least 1 standard deviation above average?
code:
pnorm(1)  # proportion below[1] 0.8413447
1-pnorm(1) # proportion above[1] 0.1586553

heading: 22.2.0.2 (b) How many standard deviations away from average is the 25th percentile of SAT scores?
text:
Answer: 25th percentile SAT scores (normally distributed values) 0.67 standard deviations average. also find value using answer (1b):\[
z = \dfrac{533 - 580}{70} = -0.67
\]
